title: Fully parametric NACA 4 digit Airfoil/Wing profile

description.text: Fully parametric NACA 4 digit Airfoil/Wing profile calculator NOw includes Eliptical and semi eliptical wing profiles too! Copyright 2011. Author: David Buzz. email: [email protected] for more details, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NACA_airfoil The default profile is 8412, which is a popular profile.

Please change these three values ( in the top of the file) to see your preferred NACA profile.
maxcamber = 8;    // percent figure. ( valid in range 0-9 )
camberposn = 4; // tenths   ( valid in range 0-9 )
thickness = 12; //percentage relative to chord   ( valid in range 0-99 )
For example usage wings, please scroll to the very bottom of the file to see how its called.  :-)

They were scanned on a David SLS-2 system using David 4 software.

title: Yamaha RBX4A2 (40 mm) Nut for 100-70-56-43 Flatwounds

description.text:
This is a replacement nut that fits Yamaha RBX4A2 and RBX4A2M basses, and possibly others with 40 millimeter nut width. It was designed for, and tested with flatwound strings, with gauges 0.100, 0.070, 0.056 and 0.043 (Thomastik-Infeld JF34). Roundwounds would probably bite into the string slots due to the layer structure, affecting tuning stability.
I recommend printing the nut with 100% infill. It should fit very snugly into the slot, and it should hold there without any gluing. The 1st fret action is very low. If you like higher 1st fret action, you'll have to modify the mesh.

This is my first upload into the world of 3D printed mold making! This is a 2 piece mold that can be re-used multiple times to cast coasters with customized 3D printed designs! It is super easy and cheap (like, 17 cents per inner plate by my estimate) to swap out the inner plates to create new designs. I have the full instructable listed out (http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Concrete-Molding/) on how to design for this properly and how to cast the parts. I'm excited to be in the Instructable Concrete and Casting contest, so if you like it and/or decide to create your own, please vote for it on the Instructables website! (top right side of my instructable) Thank you!!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1 Z

Infill:

N/A

Notes: I use a .4 nozzle with Cura set to .35 (I find this gives stronger adhesion between strands, so wall thicknesses of 2.8.

Coating The coating for this 3D printed mold gives a mold that can be used for more and more concrete castings. The first attempt was done just with concrete on a bare PLA surface, and it tore the plastic apart. I had to peel the plastic off the concrete because it got so brittle. What I think happened was the concrete water mixture actually starting its crystallization AFTER it was absorbed into the plastic (since it absorbs water from the air so easily). Then, I guess these cement crystals just tore the structure apart. Or it was just bad plastic, I don't know.
It may need a little scaling down but I think it's okay.
Support material will keep it nicer.

title: Tweaker Thruster- LED Afterburner for FPV Drone Racing

description.text: Print > Build > USE In anticipation of our upcoming Tweaker 180 3D Printed kit, we are releasing one of the files in advance for anyone to download and print. Assembyl's Matrobot came up with a part that is both functional and stylish. This part simply slips over the posts in the rear while the LED PCB cleverly slips right in which is then trapped by the top frame and the posts. The simplicity keeps the weight down while still having incredible aesthetics. The Thruster is a modular part that was designed to perfectly integrate with the rest of the kit however it can be used just as easy by itself. It can be printed with a range of materials but due to the natural forces of crashing your quad at 70mph, we highly recommend TPE/TPU (Ninja Flex/Semi Flex). Be on the look out for the remainder of the kit at http://www.Assembyl.com. We have some incredible unique parts we can't wait to share with everyone! Also for anyone just getting into FPV racing, the Tweaker is an 180 sized FPV racing quad designed by the great Andy Shen. He has many incredible frame designs that he can hardly keep stocked on the shelf. For more information or to pick up your own Tweaker, visit http://www.shendrones.com/tweaker/

No

Yes

20

Notes: For Best results and longevity of life, print with flexible filament. Make sure the infill is low to allow light to transmit through.

Nanibirds are the creation of Josh McKible and are originally paper based 3D Modells. You can download a batch from Joshs website at http://www.nanibird.com Ever since I saw these fellas for the first time, I fell in love with them and even organised a little mass production in our local hackerspace in Hamburg: http://www.baustelle-hamburg.de If you make modifications to Nanibirds, please make sure that you honor the original license which can be found at http://www.nanibird.com

This is the STL model only. I have not been able to print it yet, but results in ReplicatorG with support turned on look promising. It remains to be seen whether the feet are tall enough to support the body. Paper nanibirds tend to fall over on their head sometimes.
Future modifications would include to put a small Atmel controller inside to drive LEDs or whatsoever.

remixed_from.title: Da Vinci 1.0 Z Axis Anti Wobble Bushing Simple: easy install

title: Da Vinci 1.0 Z Axis Anti Wobble Easier Install

description.text:
I liked the idea of an easy install, but I didn't like the idea of splitting the bushing, so I decided a top down approach was the easiest for me. I, also, modified the back end to keep the bushing from rubbing on the Y axis drive rod. I put 2 holes for attaching ( You have to drill the 2nd hole through frame) for those who need it, but I found that since I keyed the bushing to the slot in the frame that one hole was more than sufficient for me. Extremely easy, no dismantling, and fast. This is dependent on how well your printer is tuned to print the bushing. I printed mine in PLA on my Wanhao D4X. 
The screw holes are 3mm. I used a 4-40 screw and nut.

Problably not for general use, but may serve as a inspiration:  
Curved slot nut fits into the slot of a canopy rail and keeps the curtain in place. Time from the start (wife complaining about direct sun in the evening) to completion <1h  
Mirror part if needed, locking must occur against force of slider, of course.

IMPORTANT The stopper locks itself because of the shape of the slot nut and the torsion applied. Such plastic parts will not work with press fit only! Spring tension because of press fit will vanish over time, plastic will creep when spring loaded constantly. Part shown needed almost brute force to insert for the first time. Now, after two weeks, it slides into position with almost no effort.

In the pictures you'll see a photocopier lens, as it's cylindrical I printed a couple of tight washers to hold it in place and also avoid light entrance.
Photos made with this, in wet plate collodion.

author: samuelsommer

title: HoHoHo Tissue - A hexagonal chain mail V3

description.text:
This is a multi-level version of my snowflake chain mail.
Now you can use the Customizer to change the dimensions. The OpenScad Script was rewritten from scratch using the polyhedron function. There are only horizontal, straight bridges. So It should be easy to print it. The name "HOHOHO" derives from the two level shape of the chain mail. H is similar to the area with a bridge in the middle. The O is similar to the area with bridges on top and bottom. The parameters I used are my minimum settings for printing.
Let me see how small you can scale down a chain mail with many elements.

comments.text: Hello. I love the design! My 3D printer (M3D Micro) has a very small build area so I can only print the chainmail in a small section. I'm not sure if it is possible, but could you try to create a model where you can fit one section into the other? Thanks!

title: Digital Camera Adaptive System for Handicapped People

description.text: This equipment group can be printed and mounted to a stand so that someone in a wheelchair with very limited mobility of their hands can still use a digital camera with control over pan, tilt, zoom, and shutter. Most digital cameras have tiny buttons and controls requiring fine motor skills and are not usable by people with hand disabilities (arthritis, cerebral palsy, etc). I created this device as part of a project for a class I was in. My mother in law, who has severe rheumatoid arthritis and has very limited fine motor skills of her hands, tested this adaptive equipment and found she could easily use it to take photos with a Sony digital camera. The controls could be tweaked to work with other types of digital cameras as well. The setup was powered by Arduino Uno. Three microservos (zoom, shutter, pan) and a standard servo (tilt) and seven microswitches were used to bring it all together for electronics hardware. I created a wooden mount box that would fit on a wheelchair tray.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm layer thickness

Infill:

30%

You will need to build or find a mounting system to mount everything together. Different cameras will need a different type of Camera Mount file. A Canon camera is probably the best, because I am told you can wire shutter and zoom controls through the USB port in a Canon camera. I had to use a Sony because it was all I had, so I had to use two servos. It would probably be much simpler with a Canon camera, because two of the servos should not be needed if you can electronically control the shutter and zoom on your camera of choice.
I included the Arduino Uno code file that will control the system.

Short Intake for 2010 Subaru STI. Utilizes factory tubing, etc. Requires an air filter, and a fabricated bracket of your choice. The air foil and MAF tubing area was made to be exactly the same shape as inside the factory air box for accurate metering. Should be printed in ABS and vapor treated if possible for maximum strength / heat resistance. I have had one on my car for almost a year in Indiana with no issues of warping / breaking. To install, remove your air box, install the short intake with filter. Remove the MAF sensor from your factory air box and install in the short intake. Fabricate a bracket to go from the mounting hole of the factory air box up to the tab on the side of the intake tube and bolt it in with the factory hardware, plus another nut/bolt/lock-washers from your stash / hardware store. BE WARNED THAT THIS REQUIRES AN ECU RE-TUNE. I DO NOT WARRANTY THE PERFORMANCE OF YOUR ENGINE IF YOU INSTALL THIS. IT HAS NOT BEEN TESTED FOR EMISSIONS AND IS FOR OFF-ROAD USE ONLY

CHEST armor. I advise you know what you're doing if you're gonna wear it.
Copyright bungie, STL Generator.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. It is a keychain with Icons from Android OS.
I got inspiration from the iOS App Icon Keychains made by pixil3d.

The thickness is 1,6 mm for the base and 3,2mm total.  
Slice with Z 0.18 mm and you get 8 layers as base, then from nineth layer the icon starts. Do a filament change when the icon starts to print and you get nice multicolored stuff...   
Here you get a lot of different ones, not related to apps, but to system.  STL are for individual icons.  
Three "plates" contain the whole set, ready to be printed as G-Code, 12 at a time. Load G-Code files on a RepRap compatible with 20 x 20 cm printing plate and save slicing time.  
Gallery Icon has two versions, if you print with two colors, you find out why (choose a transparent PLA color like blue or red.).  
Some Icons are multi level for added coolness.

This was created for a serial VFD character display.  I don't recall the exact model of the display, sorry.
Prints with no support!

description.text: This computer case foot (CF1-AP280) was designed to replace the (short) factory foot, as the large Antec P280 computer case was sinking too far into carpet and chocking off the air supply to the PSU (power supply). Informational video can be viewed on SBS Extensions YouTube Channel (click link for video).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

Any

Notes: SUGGESTED ITEM PRINT SETTINGS No Raft - No Supports - Any Infill % - 3 Shells Recommended (if not printed with 100% Infill)
PLEASE NOTE:
  • STL file was saved in the suggested printing orientation, in order to avoid the use of supports.
  • Part has been designed for ABS filament, PLA will have different tolerance at 100% scale.
  • Center hole was designed for M5 screw (or #10-24UNF or #10-32UNC).
  • Minimum recommended screw length: 11mm or 0.5 inches.
  • Center hole has 0.3 degree draft/taper to accommodate easier insertion of screw.
  • M5 or #10 tap can be used for ease of tapping threads, however screw can be threaded in by hand-tool without thread tap.
  • Circular recess (on bottom of foot) accommodates silicon-rubber pad found on factory Antec P280 foot, which is reusable.

*Note- I don't think a printed pin is going to be satisfactory. Going to redesign to use a machine screw and captive nut, or maybe a machine screw with a machine screw post. Trying to find the appropriate dimensions, but may have to go to the hardware store and get the measurements myself. I haven't printed this yet, so I don't know how well it will work. But the idea is that you use these as adjustable blocks when clamping material down. Please see the picture I attached. Note: The actual picture is not mine. I found it via an image search. The idea is from http://tomstechniques.com/tutorials/stack-blocks/ Print 1 Top Block, 1 Bottom Block, 10 Middle Blocks and 1 Pin Shaft. The pin shaft is designed to fit this quantity, per the design drawing.

comments.text: You might want to research "Machinist Jack" as that seems to be the sort of item I think you are trying to fabricate here. Otherwise the traditional machinist item to use are "step blocks" which come in various sizes and can be locked onto one another to set various heights, as well as for clamping parts via bars which mate to the steps in the blocks.

comments.text: Ambient air temperatures that are too low can cause printed layers to not stick together well, or to delaminate. By enclosing the build area, heat generated by the motors and extruder will stay in the build area, increasing the ambient temperature, and improving the prints. Also, it will protect people and animals from coming into contact with the hot extruder accidentally.

title: Nozzle Viewing Shroud and Blower Fan Mount for Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
UPDATE: 10-25-2016: Wanhao i3 PLUS design is here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850770 UPDATE: 10-06-2016: This will not work for the Wanhao i3 PLUS. Should have one designed and proven for that printer next week. UPDATE: 10-08-2015
Newest Fan Shroud (ver8) and Fan Guard (ver2) is loaded. This mounts very rigid to the machine. It was designed to use #4 x 3/8" screws to mount to the machine and #6 x 1" long screws to mount the Blower Fan and Grill to the mount and together.
I used 1.010 (101%) scale when I printed. Just print 4 of one of the nozzles also and your all set. UPDATE: 10-05-2015
Thanks to everyone and their interest. One of the issues I have dealt with, with the current design, is the shroud letting loose / tilting off of the Fan housing sometimes. I've updated the design so the shroud includes a new mount to the machine. This installs much easier and makes a very solid shroud (2nd photo of new shroud). I've got a couple of alignment issues to work out yet but I hope to have it on the site in the next couple of days. It does use the same Air nozzles and Fan Grille. ORIGINAL:
I'm a newbie to 3d printing and just purchased the Wanhao Duplicator i3 recently. I wanted better cooling so I had a better cooler installed on it. This works very well, but I had one major issue with it and all other shrouds, I could not see the nozzle anymore. I couldn't easily watch those first layers go down to see if everything looked good. So I designed this to use a low profile shroud ring with 4 additional air nozzles you glue onto it. There are alignment ribs on the air nozzles, and multiple air nozzle designs, #01 is the best in my opinion. You do have to do some fitting of the air nozzles to the shroud before gluing. For mounting the bracket to the machine use 2 #4 x 1/2" screws. This is to make sure the angled screw mount will still go through the mount bracket on the machine. The mount holes in the bracket are sized for the screw also. I did add pads to the shroud and found this to be the better file to print ABS in. That round end really likes to curl up, not much holding it down with all the air openings. I just used supports in the main neck area, which you can remove easily. I used this fan.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00

title: Gear Block to Extend Throw on Universal Power Door Lock Actuator

description.text: Universal Power Door Lock Actuators are amazing, powerful, simple, cheap devices that have tons of uses. However, they have a relatively short throw. I intended to change that.. This is a gear block that can be used to extend the throw on universal power door lock actuator mechanisms to around 90mm from the original ~40 mm. Break open the casing of the actuator, remove the original rack gear, cut off the actuator end of the casing and make a hole in the closed end of the actuator for the new rack gear to extend through. Close the case back up with the new block installed. The only drawback is that there is no buillt-in stops after the modification. Whatever you are actuating will have to provide the endstops.. I will be using them to open and shut 4" blast gates for a dust collection system in a wood shop. I'll be making seals for the actuator case out of the fingers from a household rubber glove (or something similar) to prevent sawdust, etc from getting inside. I have a modified version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1057723 that is longer and includes an end-stop, as well as an arm and mount to attach to a 4" dust collection gate.

This is a micro scale RC airplane designed to essentially snap together from common hobby store supplies. It can be assembled with the aid of a little superglue reinforcement in under 20 min post printing. VIDEO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q2kgXI0ZaCQ&feature=youtu.be Printed using Tough Resin on a Form 1, I'm fondly calling her the 'Air-Form 1.' It took 3 design iterations but this final version is a superb flyer. weighing roughly 60 grams, she is a micro plane but the dihedral wing make her very stable even in a couple kts of breeze. The motor mount/gearbox, wing clamp, and both the rudder and elevator hinges and clips were all printed out with tough resin. The main body is a rectangular carbon fiber rod and the wings are 2 rectangular balsa sheets. The motor and gearing is a replacement motor/geartrain for a laTrax quadcopter. The receiver is a specktrum ar6410 battery: 150mAh
thrust: 54g
weight: 60g
wingspan: 58cm
dihedral: 15deg
flight time: 11min Non-Printed Parts:
specktrum ar6410
150mAh battery
laTrax motor
laTrax bearings
laTrax gear/propshaft
laTrax prop
3/32in X 7/32in X 3ft rectangular carbon rod
3/16in carbon tube
7/64 carbon rod
3ft X 3in X 3/32 balsa board
1/32in music wire
superglue I'm hoping to add landing gear in the future!

title: Flashforge Dreamer/Dremel Idea Builder GoPro mount.

description.text: Wanted a simple mount that I could directly attach any GoPro compatible attachment to and hang it inside the Printer closest to the print without getting in the way of the bed or print head using minimal parts. So I remixed Shaker's mount and put it on a diet. Mount is now a lot smaller, more printer friendly, uses less material and prints much faster. I also made it a little more snug as the original was a little too loose for my liking. The second reason for this remix was so that I could mount another design I made close to the print, a triple 50mm fan mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051684 Check it out and let me know what you think and thanks to Shaker for the original design.

author: MultiRotorManiac

description.text: I developed the tall/twisted 'chimney' vase to test out the overall print volume of my C-Bot Printer: In the image, it's the tall twisted vase on the right. The Diamond vase (on the left) was created next, and they both currently sit on either side of my chimney. As printed, the Chimney Vase it's 280mm wide, and 508mm tall. The Diamond Vase is 220mm wide and 370 mm tall. But obviously you can scale either of them to whatever size you'd like. On a side node, if you flip the Chimney Vase over, it works well as a drum :)

Rafts:

No

500 micron

None

Notes: I sliced this them both in Simplify3D's 'vase mode', using my 1mm E3D-v6 Volcano nozzle. Because of that, I sliced with 500 micron layer heights, one shell. Printed in Gray PLA, the Chimney Vase took 4.5 hours at that size, and the Diamond Vase was 3 hours: A floor was created on both, but no roof.

description.text: Newb here, please be nice ;) I quickly designed this in TinkerCad so that I could mount (3) 50mm fans directly in front of my build area to help when printing anything with a lot of overhangs/bridging. Any 3 standard 50mm fans should pressure fit perfectly if your printer is true. I mount this to my other design made for my Flashforge Dreamer/Dremel Idea Builder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051672 Enjoy! Update: New STL uploaded due the lip being a couple mm thicker on one side than the other. This has been fixed for aesthetic reasons only and does not affect the functionality or fitting of the fans for those who have already printed the first version. I wouldn't have even noticed it until my buddy started closely analyzing it....ha ha. Nevertheless, the version you see now is all fixed up. Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Any resolution will look good with such a model.

Infill:

At least 20% but the more the better as the frame will flex less when adjusting the mount.

Notes: Shouldn't need supports if printed laying flat with the retaining frame lip facing the build platform. There are 2 versions for download, one without supports and one with 2 very small supports on the GoPro style mounting connector already added if you want to play it super safe. The one printed in the photo was done without supports, .30 layers, 25% infill with 3 shells on a Dremel Idea Builder that has a layer cooling fan.

comments.text: I was thinking of designing some fancy duct work using the original blower fan near the nozzle. This idea seems much simpler, how well does it work for you?
comments.author: Distrait

comments.text: Originally I wasn't getting quite enough cooling using a 5V 500ma power adapter, but since then changed to a 10v 400ma and it's pushing a descent amount of air thus improving my prints. It's super simple and cheap so it works for me. Let me know if you ever do design a vent that surrounds the nozzle using the stock blower fan as that would be the ideal solution!

comments.text: I don't think the stock blower fan is that powerful, I like your Idea and I'm going to modify it for some fans I have laying around and see if it shows improvement :)

title: Cherry Pi / Openbuilds End Stop Switch Mount

description.text:
With the Cherry Pi or other Delta printers, the only way to adjust tower height is adjusting either the top mount or the Stepper motor position - If your belts get loose (common during initial build and burn in) you'll need to make adjustments, frequently requiring re-calibration.
This end stop holder permits belt tension adjustment (via either motor movement or top mount) and use of the more common (yet slightly larger) end stop switches.
This part is designed for use with Openbuilds extrusion with a 10mm m5 bolt, but most likely will work with any 20x20mm extrusion. Additionally the more angular corner is for permitting movement of the belt used in 2020 extrusion based delta designs. 
Note: I've included a "Stop/Break" into where the switch can be inserted making it impossible to insert switches the wrong way. Please note the annotation on the side of the item. This also stops the switch from moving once it's settled.
Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: The Eyepiece and Stage Templates should be printed to provide a template to trace around the 3mm acrylic sheet.

description.text:
Smartphone microscope for turning your camera equipped smartphone into a digital microscope with a movable stage and optional illumination. Features:
  • Recessed Eyepiece to minimize scratches as some smartphone's camera housing (e.g. Samsung S3) is not flush with it's back.
  • Recessed Stage supports so microscopes can be stacked side by side when using 20mm (3/4) long Stage bolts.
  • Optional removable Illumination Box (print the base without the slots if you do not want to use the box).
    • Required:
  • PLA filament.
  • 3mm clear acrylic sheet (cut to size) for Eyepiece and Stage.
  • 4.76mm x 20mm (3/16 x 3/4) bolts with Wing nuts for holding the Stage.
  • Cyanoacrylate (super-glue) or 5-min Epoxy glue to glue parts together.
    • Illumination (optional): The light source for the Illumination box is from a 3 cell AAA LED Torch cut into two pieces (the lens and the switch) then wired with a 2 cell AAA battery. The illumination box and lens cap is custom designed for the following Torch so will not be suitable unless you have an identical size torch! See: http://www.thewarehouse.co.nz/red/catalog/product/Necessities-Brand-9-LED-Torch-Assorted-Colours?SKU=1889844

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.2mm

Infill:

30 to 50%

Notes:
  • Print in PLA not ABS due to ABS tendency to shrink, making it difficult to fit parts.
  • Recommended to print top and base at 50-60% infill to prevent warping. Print other parts at 30% infill.
  • The Eyepiece and Stage Templates should be printed to provide a template to trace around the 3mm acrylic sheet.

Assembly
  • Stage can be fitted post-assembly if bolts are ~20mm (3/4) in length.
  • Glue parts together with Cyanoacrylate (super-glue) or 5-min Epoxy glue.
  • If using the Illumination box, you will need to fit the Torch and 2 Cell AAA battery holder then solder the connections. The illumination box has a small tab at the end designed to click into place once the box is fully slid onto the base. The box and lens cap is custom designed for the following Torch so will not be suitable unless you have an identical size torch! See: http://www.thewarehouse.co.nz/red/catalog/product/Necessities-Brand-9-LED-Torch-Assorted-Colours?SKU=188984.
  • Remember to switch your smartphone camera to Macro mode for best results!
    • Smartphone microscope - assembled

description.text: Presenting a simple tripod design.  Choose between two styles of the tripod body.  One builds with the 3 leg holes facing upward.  The other is modifed with the leg holes facing downward.  Two top styles are available, a simple small one, or a larger one with ribs underneath.  Leg length, neck length can be whatever you want them to be.  The top of the tripod can easily be redone to suit your needs, I thought of making a calculator stand, a connector for my webcam..... For the legs and neck I used wooden dowels.  These could be printed easily also.  This tripod is very strong, one day I might do a failure test to see how much weight it can tolerate.

Cut wooden dowels (I used 1/4â€ diameter dowel), cut one end of each leg at 45 degrees so it will stand flat on a table.  You will likely have to ream out the dowel holes to create a tight fit for all the pieces.  See simple dimension drawing to review sizes.....

description.text: A set of gears to multiply the range of a standard servo -- a Turnigy 1501MG in this case, probably overkill -- to tilt the slats of a wooden venetian blind. Direct drive wasn't enough to get the full range of motion out of this blind. Print one pair of gears: I've found that the 25-10 teeth combo drives the full range of the blind once I tightened up the cords inside. In action: https://instagram.com/p/8aMGuzl46N/ Original gear models created using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575 A separate rig using the motor from a cordless drill and some relays to winch the blind up and down is in progress. The servo is connected to an Espruino Pico with an ESP8266 and two power regulators (5.5V for the Servo, 3.3V for the electronics) to internet-enable the setup. A simple web app controls this, along with 433MHz power relays controlling lights, desk fan, and monitors; as well as relays to control bed head/foot motors for reclining.

You should not use fans with a depth greater than 10mm for the 2x40mm version, you will get a collision with the steelframe if it's more than ~14mm thick. I dont really know the exact difference and if I have to add or subtract this difference so i just added the STP-Files so you can change it yourself (or tell me what i should change). I made it after I saw elefantman's version and used his part as a draft for mine: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:693572 Tell me what you think and how I can improve my designs :)

This is a simplified version of my original Pipe Organ. Here are the changes that have been made since the original version:
  • Hand pump removed. The wind is now produced via a mouth piece.
  • Disc Playing functionality swapped in favor of music rolls, however the organ can be printed and played via the keys without this feature.
  • These changes mean that the entire pipe organ can now be printed in a single day!
    • NB - Due to these design changes the pipes and keys are not backwards compatible. Sorry for any inconvenience! Please print, enjoy, and comment with feedback.

It took a great deal of innovative thinking to shrink the design down to this form factor.
I found the hand pump featured in the original design to be impractical at this scale and therefore opted for the wind to be supplied via a mouth piece.
The complex air channels have been completely rerouted to provide the same network in a smaller space.

You will need to print:
  • 1x Pipes
  • 1x Base
  • 8x Key
  • 1x Mouth Piece
    • Printing and Post-Printing Notes:
  • I have only printed this in PLA and that works just fine but please feel free to experiment and report back.
  • The objects are all orientated how I found it best to print, some parts (eg the mouth piece) are best printed with supports even though it requires some patience to later get the support material out of the hard to reach areas.
  • The windsheets (small slit where air escapes from the pipes) have to be very thin for functionality, they are within the tolerance of most consumer 3D printers but may require cleaning out for proper function.
  • Some parts may require filing to fit comfortably - it's better to print too big than too small!
    • Assembly:
  • Align the 8 keys with the base and push a length of 1.75 mm filament through to secure.
  • Add the pipes and mouth piece and you're ready to go.

A simplified version of kparlin's laptop HDD adapter. Much less plastic used, and only a single print, instead of 5. **v3- Made the holes a bit bigger and walls a bit thicker. Also replaced the 3 cross-members with just one, because it was taking a long time to print the 3 thin cross-members. Update 8/10/11 Added adapter that just uses bottom screws of the 2.5 inch drive, and no crossmembers. This design also has the middle mounting screw often found on 3.5 inch drives and cases.

This is a large print, so be aware that warping might be an issue.
The adapter-to-case screw holes need to be tapped, which should be easy enough by just screwing in some screws into the holes. Go slowly and back out often when it gets too tight, or else you'll probably separate the layers. Do this before trying attaching the HDD and putting it into your computer.

This is a an attempt to build a simple dualstrusion mechanism, using a single motor and single hot end. The idea was to provide with a simple upgrade possibility to many people who have a single extrusion setup. And keeping the cost low and fun high while at it!! Right now i am designing for a direct-drive setup. But this can be easily modified for a Bowden type extrusion setup. Also for the cooler, I am using an aluminium block with a heat-sink. (custom design)
but if you wanted to use a E3D v6, simple modifications could be done. Assumed limitations:
  • filament is wasted trying to avoid contamination.
  • print time is increased because it uses a single hot end.
    • The setup being designed consists of:
  • Nema 17 stepper, being used for Direct drive extruder.
  • MK8 SS drive. (9mm x 11mm - effective dia 6.8mm)
  • 1 of 624zz bearing each for the two idlers.
  • Some spring or rubber band for tension on the idler arms.
  • Standard size RC servo (~40 gms)
    • Tips:
  • Calibrate to the lowest temperature you can extrude comfortably.
  • The retraction acceleration value is kept insanely high.(to make sure there are no filament strings in the E3d after retraction)
  • I have tested only with PLA. Maybe ABS works better.

PROGRESS UPDATE: upload of the cam and an updated Servo mount. UPDATE: As i started print and assembly, i see small things to improve or errors.
just small updated part. Looks promising still. UPDATE: first dry assembly done without much issues. A few changes done to the arms to allow space for the servo arm. Two small pegs address to the end of the arms to anchor the rubber bands or spring. From the length of the arm and basic calculations it seems this cab be done with a 9gms RC servo!! To the community do write in... With thoughts to improve the design. UPDATE: Firmware still an issue. Got Marlin to (sort of) work but the motor keeps going the wrong direction! For the mechanics, there seems to be a problem with creating a sharp enough temp difference in my design, leaving the retracted end of the filament either a blob jamming the mechanism OR a long melt-cone which the MK8 drive misses.Some PTFE tube is in shipping to help solve this!! NEXT OPTION: change the design to give each of the two filaments long enough tunnel so i can live with long melt cones and still work. UPDATE: firmware -done!! Marlin with modifications.
Hardware- almost done. One filament is not extruding enough. I wonder if there mk8 drive is directional!!!?? UPDATE: a lot of changes. But I have still not given up on the initial idea of making it simple. Retraction during filament change is leaving a thin thread of filament inside the e3d causing it to jam when the next filament comes in. It would be great if someone could point me in the right direction. Wait before retraction? Very fast or slow acceleration values for the E axis?? High extrusion temp? UPDATE: uploaded the new set of files. Now it would be possible for people to download and test all the parts. Firmware still needs fine tuning. The servo position and Extruder motor direction going out of sync randomly after 3-4mm build height.

This Cute Glowing Robotic Hamster is part of a Mapping system I am developing.
It uses a ESP8266 WiFi module (Series 12) into a 3D printed Glowing chassis. It is a low cost Robot Circa $10.00 including everything. The hamster creates its own server with a tiny control panel webpage, so it can be controlled by a PC or even a Mobile Phone by using an integrated visual GUI The drive system is based on the popular 28BYJ-48 Stepper motors.
It uses 2 x Ultra Fire Lipo Batteries ( 18650 5000mAhr) for long life.
The Tyres are stamdard 5cm inside diameter 7mm round "O" rings.
The back end is fitted with a small bearing as boogie wheel.(works like magic). More details on the build can be found here :-
https://hackaday.io/project/7695-esp8266-wifi-controlled-hamster Video Here :-
https://youtu.be/FJkhSLg7_FE

A hard, printable business card case, perfect for carrying around those fragile, elaborate business cards.

You're all business, on the case, and a card to boot with this, uh, business card case.  Perfect for keeping business cards and things that are the same shape as business cards safe from the elements, accidental damage, and each other.
Both parts can be easily sliced and printed on a makerbot, reprap, or other 3D printer.  With a bit of cleaning with a knife, the top should slide on to the bottom smoothly and stay on reasonably well.
If you're printing in natural ABS and you have a lot of contrast on your card, you'll notice that the walls are thin enough to allow you to see the card faintly through the wall of the case!
(If you're using a reprap or makerbot, make sure that the first layer of your build/raft is squished down on the build platform a bit, to prevent the build from curling and peeling.)

title: OpenSCAD script to print mathematical bidimensional functions

description.text:
Spanish: (See below for english)
Esto es un simple script que hice para poder imprimir realmente funciones matemáticas. Toda la vida las he visto pintadas en 2D o imaginadas en mi mente. Así que porque no imprimirlas de verdad? Esto es tan simple que solo elijes tu formula favorita, pones los limites/intervalos de los valores y ya está. Exporta e imprímela. Cuidado, más de 150 segmentos puede ser muuuuy lento de calcular. Me gustaría mejorar esto así que dime algo si puedes echar una mano. English:
This is a simple script I made to be able to print the real mathematical functions. All my life I have seen them drawn in 2D or ever imagined them in my mind. So, why not print the real thing? This is so simple that you just pick up your favourite formula, enter the intervals/limits of the values and your are done! Export and print it!!! Watch out, more than 150 slices could be sloooow to render. I would like to enhance this so drop me a line if you can help.

comments.text: Why not? We just need the formula. But think of this: What about optical properties? We are talking about polymers. About molds, well, not enough resolution.Maybe the future deserve us brand new awesome materials...

title: Spinner for R/C model folding prop (e.g. MPX Merlin)

description.text:
Spinner Cap for R/C model with 2 blade folding propeller.
The model is done completely parametric in OPENSCAD with a procedural generated hyperbolic shape. With the uploaded dimensions it fits to a MPX Merlin (with DIY Alu central prop hub). With slight modifications (increased dimensions and different connection to Alu hub) I use the same design for MPX Easyglider and even my Cularis. Hyperbolic shape can be modified by exponent from 1.0 (linear cone shape) to 2.0 (ball shape), I experienced exponent = 1.7 fits to most gliders of these types - just feel free to play with the parameters! A small support structure can be switched on/off in the openscad source code, no additional support is required. STL files are supported with and w/o support structure.

author: HenningS

description.text:
Honeycomb bookstand, designed for medium-large books. Maximum book thickness 46 mm.
Maximum recommended book size is around 20×30 cm, taller books might shift the center of gravity and make the stand tip backwards
The honeycomb pattern is decorative, but .also saves around 60% material.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.19 mm or less

Infill:

25% or more recommended

Notes: I printed it without support, and it came out rather nice, needing only a little cleanup.
For best results, support is recommended though – but it will double the required material from around 30 grams to over 60 grams :-( I printed it with 0.19 mm layers in Z-ABS on my Zortrax M200 – for smoother details 0.14 mm layers is recommended, but less than that most likely won’t yield a better result, only take up more time to print.

This is a battery holder for quadcopters. This holder allows a solid mount of the battery, so it doesn't wiggle during the flight, and it allows to do acrobatics without losing the battery in air.
I use it for the quadcopter with a frame Q450 V3 from Hobby King, but it can also be mounted on other frames. To mount this holder you can use 4 M4 holes on the bottom of the holder. To fix the battery in a holder one can use standard battery straps. Battery holder ca be mounted either on top or on the bottom of the frame. In my example it is mounted on the top. It is designed for two types of batteries:
1) 119(length)x35(height)x32(width)mm, for example Turnigy nanotech 2.2 4S, 25-50C
2) 175(length)x49(height)x38(width)mm, for example Turnigy nanotech 6.0 4S, 25-50C There are three STL files:
1) the complete structure
2) Structure cut in two pieces to print it with Printrbot Simple Wood. You can glue two parts using glue for hard plastic. Enjoy!

This adapter is to enable use of rigid.ink filament spools with a 20mm spool rod such as that used with the Flashforge Dreamer and Omnimount stand supports.  You will need a pair of these for each rigid.ink spool you wish to use.  Simply insert one in each side of the spool and then feed the spool rod through the hole at each end.  
The benefit of using this pair is that you do not need to print a full 70mm+ wide adapter thus saving printing time and filament.
